content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

I see approximately six discrete pieces of tissue on this slide, consistent with lymph nodes resected for staging. They vary in size and shape. The overall architecture shows well-circumscribed nodules of dense purple (lymphoid) tissue, with some exhibiting lighter, circular areas suggestive of lymphoid follicles. The nodes are embedded in pink-staining adipose and fibrous connective tissue. My initial task would be to systematically examine each of these nodes for evidence of metastasis.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into this specific area because it is located at the periphery of the first lymph node (top left). When looking for colorectal cancer metastasis in a lymph node, the first place tumor cells typically deposit is in the subcapsular sinus, which lies just beneath the lymph node capsule. Therefore, carefully examining the entire periphery of each node is a critical and high-yield step in the screening process. This is a systematic approach to start the evaluation of this particular node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the task is to systematically examine every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The green box is located on the first lymph node on the top left. The pathologist is likely beginning their review with this node. The specific location of the zoom is near the periphery of the node, close to the capsule. This is a critical area to examine at high power because metastatic cancer cells often first colonize the subcapsular sinuses. Therefore, this zoom is a standard part of a thorough search for micrometastases. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the periphery of the first lymph node at the top left. The reason for examining this specific location is that metastatic tumor cells, which travel through the lymphatic system, typically first arrive and implant in the subcapsular sinus, an area just beneath the outer capsule of the lymph node. A systematic examination of any lymph node for metastasis requires careful inspection of the entire capsule and subcapsular sinus. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic examination of each lymph node. This specific location, the second node from the left in the top row, is targeted at its periphery. The subcapsular sinus, located just beneath the capsule, is the most common initial site for metastatic carcinoma cells to deposit after arriving via afferent lymphatic vessels. Therefore, scrutinizing this region is a critical, high-yield step in ruling out or identifying micrometastases. Additionally, there appears to be green ink on the capsule, which often marks a surgical or specific anatomical surface, making the underlying tissue even more important to examine. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the fifth lymph node from the top (the one on the lower left). The specific area is the periphery of the node, encompassing the capsule and the surrounding fatty tissue. This is a high-yield area to scrutinize because metastatic cells from colorectal cancer typically travel through lymphatic vessels and first deposit in the subcapsular sinus. I am looking for any atypical cell clusters or architectural distortions that would suggest the presence of a tumor deposit or extranodal extension. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is the periphery (subcapsular region) of the large lymph node at the bottom right. Metastatic cancer cells from carcinomas typically travel via the lymphatics and first deposit in the subcapsular sinus of a lymph node. Therefore, screening the entire periphery of each lymph node is the most efficient and highest-yield method for detecting metastases. This particular area at the edge also seems to have a slightly different color and texture, raising suspicion. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area, which is the third tissue section from the left in the top row, because the periphery of the lymph node appears abnormal. The edge is not smooth and encapsulated like a typical lymph node. Instead, it looks irregular and jagged, with lymphoid tissue appearing to infiltrate or being infiltrated by the surrounding fatty and fibrous tissue. This pattern is highly suspicious for extranodal extension of metastatic tumor, a critical finding when staging cancer. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see the cortex of the lymph node. There is a dense population of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes. A lymphoid follicle is present, characterized by a slightly paler germinal center containing larger lymphocytes and a surrounding darker mantle zone. The lymph node capsule and adjacent adipose tissue are visible in the upper right. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, abnormal glandular structures, or nests of tumor cells. My impression of this specific field is that it represents a reactive, benign lymph node with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a dense and uniform population of small lymphocytes with dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm. At the bottom of the image, the lymph node capsule and surrounding adipose tissue are visible. There are no signs of metastatic tumor in this specific field. I do not see any atypical glands, clusters of large pleomorphic cells, or individual signet ring cells that would indicate metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this area is that it is a benign part of the lymph node, likely representing cortical lymphoid tissue. It appears negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I can clearly see the interface between the lymph node and the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue. On the left is the dense lymphoid parenchyma of the node. On the right is mature adipose tissue. The area of interest is the subcapsular sinus, located just under the fibrous capsule. There is a prominent ink artifact, likely from a marker pen on the slide, which partially obscures the view. In the visible areas of the subcapsular sinus, I see lymphocytes and some sinus histiocytes. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glands, or nests of tumor cells to suggest metastasis. My impression for this specific field is that it is negative for metastasis, but I would need to continue examining the entire periphery of this node and all other nodes on the slide.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the periphery of the lymph node. At the top is the fibrous capsule, coated with green surgical ink, and adjacent adipose tissue. Just beneath the capsule is the subcapsular sinus and the cortical lymphoid tissue. The lymphoid tissue is dense and composed of lymphocytes. There are prominent lymphoid follicles, some with germinal centers, which is characteristic of a reactive lymph node (follicular hyperplasia). I do not see any atypical epithelial cell clusters, glandular structures, or single infiltrating malignant cells within the subcapsular sinus or the parenchyma in this field. My impression of this specific area is that it is a reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see the edge of the lymph node's lymphoid tissue on the lower right. The rest of the image shows the lymph node capsule and surrounding perinodal fibro-adipose tissue. Within this perinodal tissue, there are infiltrating clusters and poorly formed glands of atypical cells. These cells are large, have pleomorphic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and eosinophilic cytoplasm, which are features of adenocarcinoma. My impression is definitive for metastatic adenocarcinoma. Importantly, the tumor is located outside the main lymph node parenchyma, indicating extranodal extension, which is a significant prognostic factor.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see the edge of the lymph node. The subcapsular sinus is expanded and filled with clusters of atypical cells that are clearly not lymphocytes. These cells are larger, have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and large, irregular, vesicular nuclei. They are forming poorly-defined glandular structures. Black pigment, likely tattoo ink from colonoscopy marking, is also present. My definitive impression is that this is metastatic adenocarcinoma infiltrating the subcapsular sinus of the lymph node. This is a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I can see the edge of a lymph node, characterized by the dense sheet of dark purple lymphocytes. At the top of the image is pericapsular adipose (fat) tissue. The key finding is the clear infiltration of clusters and nests of atypical, malignant-appearing cells extending from the lymph node parenchyma out into the surrounding fat. These cells are not lymphocytes; they are consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node showing metastatic carcinoma with definite extranodal extension (ENE).
